head.title: For Turks, Time to Shout 'Hello, Europe!'

hedline.hl1: For Turks, Time to Shout 'Hello, Europe!'

abstract.p: Turkey, soccer-crazed country, is ecstatic after Istanbul soccer team wins first major European championship ever won by Turkish team; victory has importance far beyond sports; it speaks of Turkey's growing self-confidence that country can succeed at any level if it disciplines itself and embraces European rules; this is remarkable moment in Turkish history; during last year country has seen apparent end of long civil war, has been invited to apply for membership in European Union, and has begun making peace with Greece, its longtime rival (M)

block.p: Early this morning, after the Istanbul soccer team Galatasaray won the first major European championship ever won by a Turkish team, the coach, Fatih Terim, said he had one more wish.

Early this morning, after the Istanbul soccer team Galatasaray won the first major European championship ever won by a Turkish team, the coach, Fatih Terim, said he had one more wish.
''I hope our country follows up on this,'' Mr. Terim said during the jubilation, ''not just in soccer but in every field.''
Most people in this soccer-crazed country spent today both proud and ecstatic. In a century of competition, no Turkish team has even come close to such a triumph.

But Galatasaray's 4-1 victory in a penalty shootout over the British team, Arsenal, has an importance far beyond sports. It spoke of this country's growing self-confidence and encouraged the increasing number of Turks who say that Turkey can succeed at any level if it disciplines itself and embraces European rules.

Mr. Terim is an ideal symbol of the transition Turkey hopes to make. Once a young tough who got into fights in bars, he has blossomed into an articulate leader who plays by Europe's rules and comes out a winner.

''This is much bigger than football,'' said Serif Erol, a radio commentator who spent much of his Thursday morning show discussing the big victory in the Ufea Cup, given by the Union of European Football Associations.

''Turkey has been missing success for much too long,'' Mr. Erol said. ''We started to wonder if we could ever compete with Europe. Now we're losing some of that inferiority complex. It's a sign of the reversal in our psychology. If we can beat so many great European teams on the soccer field, that makes us think we can be as good as the rest of Europe in democracy, in human rights, in everything.''

Wednesday night's game, which was played in Copenhagen, gave Galatasaray the right to call itself the best soccer club in Europe. On its way to the championship, it defeated top teams not just from Britain but also from Germany, Italy and other longtime soccer powers.

The victory came at a remarkable moment in Turkish history. During the last year this country has seen the apparent end of a long civil war, has been invited to apply for membership in the European Union, and has begun making peace with Greece, its longtime rival.
